The HAZOP What-if/Checklist study was conducted July 27, 2022 for the ammonia system. The PHA was facilitated by Jose Chavez who is knowledgeable on the PHA methodology. The PHA involved Joseph Boyd (Director of Engineering) and Esteban Infante (Safety Coordinator) who are knowledgeable on the process. The PHA resulted in two recommendations.

OPERATING PROCEDURES

 Written procedures have been developed to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in the process consistent with the process safety information. A copy of these operating procedures will be readily accessible to all employees who work in or near the process area of to other persons who work in or near the area including contractors and maintenance personnel.

Anhydrous Ammonia Procedures:
- Unloading from the truck.
- Start-up of the liquid injection process.
- Emergency shutdown of the liquid injection process.
- Emergency shutdown.
- Replacement of  pressure relief valves.
- Startup of the liquid injection process after emergency shutdown.
- Pump-down and evacuation of the storage tank for servicing.
-  Refilling of the storage tank after pump-down and evacuation.
- Recovery of ammonia vapors.
- Operation of the burner.
- Emergency shutdown of the vapor recovery system and burner.
- Emergency response to a small or large release of anhydrous ammonia vapor and liquid.

Aqueous Ammonia Procedures:
- Operation of the aqua injection system.
- Emergency shutdown of the aqua injection system.
- Transfer of the aqua ammonia liquid.
- Storage of the aqua ammonia liquid.
- Application of the aqua ammonia liquid to other products.
- Emergency response to aqua ammonia liquid release.

EMERGENCY PLANNING & RESPONSE

The typical meteorological conditions used for these scenarios was a stability class D, wind speed 3.0 m/s, average air temperature , and average humidity.

PREVENTION PROGRAM

The general accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
- High level of training of the operators.
- Preventative maintenance programs.
- Use of state-of-the-art  process and safety equipment.
Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of operators.
- Performance of a process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures. 
- Implementation of an auditing and inspection program.

ISP will fully implement the RMP and will initiate appropriate changes as needed to maintain a safe operation.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no reportable releases at IWP in the past five years.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The RMP requires that the facility be capable of furnishing safety information regarding chemicals and equipment employed in the applicable process. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and used at the facility for the fumigation of seed. Aqueous ammonia is produced as a byproduct of the seed fumigation operation. 

The anhydrous ammonia system includes one above ground storage tank ammonia pump, associated piping, hoses and valves for the transfer of ammonia from delivery trucks into the process. The Process Safety Information document contains information on Operating Limits, Equipment Specifications, SDS, Ammonia health hazards, Codes and Standards applied, Materials of construction, and Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams. 

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The identification of potential hazards due to operational and system failures has been performed though the use of a Hazards and Operability (HAZOP) and What-if/checklist study. The hazard analysis documents t

es technologies, procedures, and management practices. All applicable procedures of the CalARP are adhered to. The IWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of response plans which are tailored to the facility and to the emergency response serviced available in the community.

MAXIMUM INTENDED INVENTORY

IWP has the capacity to store  19,532 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia at its Coachella facility. The ammonia is stored in one bulk storage tank that is filled to 75% of capacity as an administrative limit.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
Atmospheric dispersion modeling has to be performed to determine, if the substance is accidentally released, the distance the toxic substance could travel before it is concentration decreases to the toxic endpoint selected by the EPA (0.14 mg/L for anhydrous ammonia). The toxic endpoint is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the maximum airborne concentration below which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action. The residential population within a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance has to be defined, to estimate the population potentially affected.

The offsite consequence analysis includes consideration of two release scenarios for the process, identified as Worst Case Release and Alternative Release Scenario.

The Worst Case Release scenario at IWP involves the release of all anhydrous ammonia containing product. The total amount of anhydrous ammonia that potentially could be released would amass to approximately 95,532 pounds (lbs). The offsite consequences analysis for this scenario was performed for the following set of conditions.

When atmospheric modeling for the WCS was performed using EPA assumptions, a distance to the toxic endpoint of 3.7 miles and an estimate of population potentially affected 41,148 persons were obtained for the release scenario.

The ARS involved the release of 14,314 pounds of anhydrous ammonia with a distance to toxic endpoint a

IWP utilizes anhydrous ammonia for the treatment of cottonseed. The anhydrous ammonia is combined with steam to destroy aflatoxin that may be present in cottonseed.

WIWP maintains their ammonia onsite. Due to the nature of the operations, the ammonia is consumed. The ammonia is supplied by various vendors and brought in by tank truck.

The principle hazards associated with this process are the toxic and irritating effects of ammonia. Both the gas and liquid phases exist within the process . IWP uses both phases during the cottonseed treatment at the facility. Ammonia itself can cause sever irritation of the throat and irritation of the eyes and the skin on contact. Inhalation of high concentrations can cause pulmonary edema or a spasm of the larynx which can result in death. Ammonia itself is a colorless liquified compressed gas under its own vapor pressure (2327 mmHg @ 32F). The odor of the ammonia is an extremely pungent kind.

IWP minimized the hazards associated with ammonia using engineering and administrative controls including the following:
- Transfer operations occur in  open air.
- Check valves, relief valve, manual shutoff valves, and other devices are utilized to protect the process and employees.
- No ammonia is vented to the open air during normal operations.
- No transfer operations are permitted unless at least two employees are present.
- All transfer lines and valves are checked prior to each used. Leak checks are performed on all lines.
- All process lines are evacuated with air before work is performed on any section of the system.
- All personnel are thoroughly trained in the hazards of the operation and the proper procedures to be followed before they are allowed to work with the process.
- An eye-wash and deluge fountain are located adjacent to the storage areas.
